intro: Sebastiania corniculata var. potamophila, commonly known as the water sycamore, is a flowering plant native to southern Mexico and Central America. It is a member of the Euphorbiaceae family and is characterized by its opposite, ovate leaves with a waxy surface. The plant produces small, greenish-yellow flowers in clusters, which are followed by orange-red berries. It thrives in moist, well-drained soils near water bodies, making it a common sight in riparian zones. Its ornamental value and ability to tolerate wet conditions make it a popular choice for wetland landscaping.
